OVERVIEW: The Bagger series consists of deep to very deep, well drained altered soils that formed in fill material derived from mixed but dominantly granitic sources that has been mixed by land leveling. Bagger soils are on terraces, and drainageways that have been filled and leveled due to land leveling activities.  Slopes are 0 to 2 percent. The mean annual precipitation is about 17 inches and the mean annual temperature is about 60 degrees F.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, active, nonacid, thermic Alfic Xerarents

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
REFERENCE PEDON:  Bagger sandy loam on a nearby level slope of less than 1 percent in a sudan grass field at 50 feet elevation. (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise stated.  When described on November 6, 1976, the soil was moist throughout.)
Ap--0 to 9 inches; mixed pale brown and yellowish brown (10YR 6/3, 5/4) sandy loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; massive; hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine, fine and medium roots; many very fine and fine interstitial pores; about 10 percent by volume 2 to 35 mm hardpan fragments which can be broken by hand; hardpan fragments have same color as soil matrix; neutral (pH 7.2); gradual smooth boundary. (4 to 12 inches thick)
2C1--9 to 16 inches; mixed light gray, white and brown (2.5Y 7/2, 8/2; 7.5Y 5/4) light sandy clay loam, grayish brown and brown (2.5Y 5/2; 7.5YR 4/4) moist; massive; hard, friable, sticky and slightly plastic; few very fine roots; common very fine and fine interstitial pores; common thin silica colloids bridging sand grains; about 10 percent by volume 2 to 35 mm hardpan fragments which can be broken by hand; hardpan fragments have same color as matrix; fragments of Bt (argillic) dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist clay and clay loam; about 5 percent by volume black (N 4/ ) Fe-Mn soft concretion ranging up to 5 mm in diameter; slightly calcareous with lime segregated in few fine filaments, moderately alkaline (pH 8.0); clear wavy boundary.  (0 to 20 inches thick)
3C2--16 to 30 inches; mixed pale brown and brown (10YR 6/3, 7.5YR 5/4) loamy sand and sandy loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3, 7.5YR 4/4) moist; massive; hard, friable, nonsticky and slightly sticky and nonplastic and slightly plastic; few very fine roots; common very fine interstitial pores; about 3 percent by volume Bt (argillic) fragments having many very fine tubular pores and common thin clay films lining the tubular pores and common thin silica colloids bridging sand grains; in small pockets 20 percent by volume 2 to 5 mm gravels encased by loamy sand fill; about 25 percent by volume 5 to 35 mm hardpan fragments within small pockets in the lower 2/3 of the horizon having the same color as the horizon matrix; few black (N 2/) 2 to 5 mm Fe-Mn flakes; mildly alkaline (pH 7.5); abrupt smooth boundary.  (0 to 20 inches thick)
4Ab--30 to 35 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; common fine distinct yellowish red (5YR 5/6) mottles, dark reddish brown (5YR 3/4) moist; massive; hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine roots; common very fine tubular and interstitial pores; 1/4 inch organic residue at top of horizon, few black (N 2/) 1 to 5 mm Fe-Mn concretions; medium acid (pH 6.0); gradual wavy boundary.  (0 to 10 inches thick)
4C3--35 to 49 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; massive; hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few very fine roots; common very fine, fine and medium tubular and common very fine and fine interstitial pores; few black (N 2/) 1 to 5 mm Fe-Mn concretions; mildly alkaline (pH 7.5); clear wavy boundary. (0 to 20 inches thick)
4Cq--49 to 60 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) fine sandy loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; massive; very hard, firm, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; no roots; few very fine interstitial pores; weakly cemented with silica; moderately alkaline (pH 8.0)

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Sacramento County, California; about 5.1 miles south of the town of Wilton, about 530 feet west and 250 feet north of the intersection of Kerry Lane and Arno Road in an unsectionized part of T.  6 N, R. 6 E.  Galt Quadrangle.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Depth to a buried soil is 20 to 60 inches in most pedons and deeper than 60 inches in a few pedons.  Depth to a duripan where present is more than 40 inches.  The soil between a depth of 8 inches to 26 inches is dry in all parts from June to November and is moist in all parts from late  December till mid April and is moist in some  part the remainder of the time.  The mean annual temperature is 64 to 67 degrees F.  It does not drop below 47 degrees F during  any part of the year.  Fragments of argillic horizon occur in some or all parts of the fill between the 10 to 40 inch zone. The fragments are not arranged in any discernable order.  Fragments of hardpan average 0 to 15 percent in the 10 to 40 inch zone. Weighted average of clay content in the 10 to 40 inch zone is 10 to 18 percent.  The fill material is as variable as its source.
The Ap horizon and C horizon are fill material.  The fill material consists of two or more colors, mixed.  It is 10YR 5/2, 5/3, 5/4, 6/2, 6/3; 2.5Y 7/2, 8/2; 7.5YR 5/2, 5/4, 5/6, 6/4, 6/6; 5YR 4/3, 4/4, 5/3, 5/4, 5/6, 6/6.  Moist colors are 10YR 3/2, 3/3, 3/4, 4/2, 4/3, 4/4, 5/3; 2.5Y 5/2; 7.5YR 3/4, 4/2, 4/4, 4/6; 5YR 3/3, 3/4, 4/3, 4/4, 4/6.  It is loamy sand to sandy clay loam but the average texture is sandy loam or loam.   Reaction ranges from medium acid to moderately alkaline.  Some subhorizons may be calcareous.
The buried soil is variable.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  There are no competing soils.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Bagger soils are on low terraces and drainageways that have been highly altered due to land leveling. They are in filled areas.  Slopes are 0 to 2 percent and are smooth. They formed in alluvium from mixed but dominantly granitic sources.  Elevations are 20 to 100 feet.  The climate is subhumid with hot dry summers and cool moist winters.  Mean annual precipitation is 13 to 17 inches.  Mean January temperature is about 44 degrees F; mean July temperature is about 75 degrees F; mean annual temperature is 59 to 61 degrees F.  The frost-free season is 250 to 300 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Galt, Madera, and San Joaquin soils.  All of these soils lack fragments of an argillic horizon below the Ap horizon.   In addition, Galt, Madera, and San Joaquin soils have fine textural control sections.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:   Well drained, very slow runoff; moderately slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Used for irrigated cropland and pastureland.  Commonly grown crops are corn and small grains.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Terraces and drainages of the east side of the Central Valley.  The soils are of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Davis, California

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Sacramento, California.  Sacramento County SSA 1986.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  This series was established to establish the subgroup of Xeralfic Arents.  The series will not be mapped. This series was reclassified in 1992 to reflect amendment 16 to Soil Taxonomy.
Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are:
Ochric epipedon -- 0 to 9 inches (Ap)
Fragments of diagnostic horizon - In 9 to 16 inch horizon. Consist of fragments of the argillic horizon from nearby cut areas.
Last revised by the state on 7/86.

HORIZONS.name: Ap
HORIZONS.narrative: Ap--0 to 9 inches; mixed pale brown and yellowish brown (10YR 6/3, 5/4) sandy loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; massive; hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine, fine and medium roots; many very fine and fine interstitial pores; about 10 percent by volume 2 to 35 mm hardpan fragments which can be broken by hand; hardpan fragments have same color as soil matrix; neutral (pH 7.2); gradual smooth boundary. (4 to 12 inches thick)

HORIZONS.narrative: 2C1--9 to 16 inches; mixed light gray, white and brown (2.5Y 7/2, 8/2; 7.5Y 5/4) light sandy clay loam, grayish brown and brown (2.5Y 5/2; 7.5YR 4/4) moist; massive; hard, friable, sticky and slightly plastic; few very fine roots; common very fine and fine interstitial pores; common thin silica colloids bridging sand grains; about 10 percent by volume 2 to 35 mm hardpan fragments which can be broken by hand; hardpan fragments have same color as matrix; fragments of Bt (argillic) dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist clay and clay loam; about 5 percent by volume black (N 4/ ) Fe-Mn soft concretion ranging up to 5 mm in diameter; slightly calcareous with lime segregated in few fine filaments, moderately alkaline (pH 8.0); clear wavy boundary.  (0 to 20 inches thick)

HORIZONS.name: 3C2
HORIZONS.narrative: 3C2--16 to 30 inches; mixed pale brown and brown (10YR 6/3, 7.5YR 5/4) loamy sand and sandy loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3, 7.5YR 4/4) moist; massive; hard, friable, nonsticky and slightly sticky and nonplastic and slightly plastic; few very fine roots; common very fine interstitial pores; about 3 percent by volume Bt (argillic) fragments having many very fine tubular pores and common thin clay films lining the tubular pores and common thin silica colloids bridging sand grains; in small pockets 20 percent by volume 2 to 5 mm gravels encased by loamy sand fill; about 25 percent by volume 5 to 35 mm hardpan fragments within small pockets in the lower 2/3 of the horizon having the same color as the horizon matrix; few black (N 2/) 2 to 5 mm Fe-Mn flakes; mildly alkaline (pH 7.5); abrupt smooth boundary.  (0 to 20 inches thick)

HORIZONS.name: 4Ab
HORIZONS.narrative: 4Ab--30 to 35 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; common fine distinct yellowish red (5YR 5/6) mottles, dark reddish brown (5YR 3/4) moist; massive; hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine roots; common very fine tubular and interstitial pores; 1/4 inch organic residue at top of horizon, few black (N 2/) 1 to 5 mm Fe-Mn concretions; medium acid (pH 6.0); gradual wavy boundary.  (0 to 10 inches thick)

HORIZONS.name: 4C3
HORIZONS.narrative: 4C3--35 to 49 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; massive; hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few very fine roots; common very fine, fine and medium tubular and common very fine and fine interstitial pores; few black (N 2/) 1 to 5 mm Fe-Mn concretions; mildly alkaline (pH 7.5); clear wavy boundary. (0 to 20 inches thick)

HORIZONS.name: 4Cq
HORIZONS.narrative: 4Cq--49 to 60 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) fine sandy loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; massive; very hard, firm, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; no roots; few very fine interstitial pores; weakly cemented with silica; moderately alkaline (pH 8.0)
